---

This is the first in a series of three blog posts. In the following
we'll investigate a few properties of an object called Conway's
topograph. [John Conway](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Horton_Conway)
conjured up a way to understand a binary quadratic form &ndash; a very important
algebraic object &ndash; in a geometric context. This is by no means original
work, just my interpretation of some key points from his
<a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0883850303/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0883850303&linkCode=as2&tag=boslobblo-20&linkId=5ZI7SBFQVULNR52O">The Sensual (Quadratic) Form</a><img src="//ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=boslobblo-20&l=as2&o=1&a=0883850303" width="1" height="1" border="0" alt="AMZN Affiliate Ad" style="border:none !important; margin:0px !important;" />
that I'll need for some other posts.

----------------------------------------------------------------

#### Definition: {#define-quadratic-form}

A binary quadratic form <html-literal></html-literal> is an equation of
the form:

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

That is, a function of two variables which is homogeneous of degree two.
The coefficients <html-literal></html-literal> <html-literal></html-literal> and
<html-literal></html-literal> and variables <html-literal></html-literal> and
<html-literal></html-literal> are often real numbers, rational numbers or integers.
<html-literal></html-literal>

When we require the coefficients <html-literal></html-literal> <html-literal></html-literal> and
<html-literal></html-literal> as well as the variables <html-literal></html-literal> to be
integers, we get an integer-valued form. In his **Disquisitiones Arithmeticae**,
Gauss asked (and largely answered) the fundamental question: what
integer values can each form take? For example, you may have seen the
form

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

where it was determined that the only primes (Gaussian primes) occuring were
<html-literal></html-literal> and those odd primes congruent to 1 modulo 4.

As each form <html-literal></html-literal> is homogenous degree two,
<html-literal></html-literal>. As a result,
if we can understand the values of <html-literal></html-literal> for pairs
<html-literal></html-literal> which don't share any factors, we can understand the
entire set of values that <html-literal></html-literal> takes. Also, letting
<html-literal></html-literal> there is no change in the value of
<html-literal></html-literal> since <html-literal></html-literal> hence it suffices
to think of <html-literal></html-literal> as <html-literal></html-literal> i.e.
<html-literal></html-literal>.

For integers <html-literal></html-literal> and <html-literal></html-literal> any point
<html-literal></html-literal> can be expressed as an integral linear combination of
the vectors <html-literal></html-literal> and
<html-literal></html-literal>. So if we like, we can express all relevant
inputs for <html-literal></html-literal> in terms of two vectors. However, instead
considering <html-literal></html-literal> we have

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

and realize a different pair <html-literal></html-literal> which again yield all
possible integer valued vectors as integral linear combinations.

#### Definition: {#define-base}

A **strict base** is an ordered pair <html-literal></html-literal> whose
integral linear combinations are exactly all vectors with integer coordinates.
A **lax base** is a set <html-literal></html-literal>
obtained from a strict base.
<html-literal></html-literal>

#### Definition: {#define-superbase}

A **strict superbase** is an ordered triple <html-literal></html-literal>
for which <html-literal></html-literal> and
<html-literal></html-literal> is a strict base (i.e., with strict vectors), and
a **lax superbase** is a set
<html-literal></html-literal> where
<html-literal></html-literal> is a strict superbase.
<html-literal></html-literal>

For our (and Conway's) purposes, it is useful to consider the lax notions and
leave the strict notions as an afterthought since a binary quadratic form is
unchanged given a sign change. From here forward, for a vector
<html-literal></html-literal> we use the notation <html-literal></html-literal> interchangeably
with <html-literal></html-literal> and when referring to a base/superbase, we are
referring to the lax equivalent of these notions.

Follow along to
[Part 2](/2011/08/conways-topograph-part-2.html).

#### Update:

This material is intentionally aimed at an intermediate (think college
freshman/high school senior) audience. One can go deeper with it, and I'd
love to get more technical off the post.
